question: [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Block cache overflow] If block_cache is shared across all column families (line 198), can an attacker fill the cache with low-value data to evict critical consensus data, forcing expensive disk reads during block proposal and breaking liveness? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Filter false positive exploitation] Can an attacker exploit the probabilistic nature of bloom filters (line 204) to craft queries that always result in false positives, forcing unnecessary disk reads and degrading query performance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_cfds()] [Non-atomic descriptor creation] Is the creation of ColumnFamilyDescriptor objects (line 176) atomic across all column families, or can a crash during initialization leave some CFs configured while others remain unconfigured, causing database corruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_cfds()] [Post-processor race] Can concurrent calls to cf_opts_post_processor (line 175) on the same cf_name cause race conditions that result in non-deterministic CF configurations across validator nodes, breaking consensus? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_cfds()] [Vector capacity overflow] Can an attacker provide a massive column family list causing Vec::with_capacity(cfs.len()) in line 167 to allocate excessive memory, triggering OOM conditions before database initialization completes? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Unbounded cache growth] If multiple databases share the same block_cache (line 198), can an attacker cause unbounded cache growth by accessing data across all databases simultaneously, exhausting node memory? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_key_extractor()] [Slice panic exploit] Can an attacker craft state_value_raw_key with length < VERSION_SIZE (line 237) to trigger a panic during prefix extraction, crashing the validator node and causing consensus disruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_kv_db_column_families()] [Stale index manipulation] Can an attacker exploit STALE_STATE_VALUE_INDEX_CF_NAME (line 135) to prevent proper pruning of old state values, causing validators to read stale data during state sync and creating inconsistent state roots? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_kv_db_new_key_column_families()] [Key hash collision attack] Can an attacker generate state keys that hash to the same value in STALE_STATE_VALUE_INDEX_BY_KEY_HASH_CF_NAME (line 145), causing incorrect stale data identification and corrupting active state? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: ledger_metadata_db_column_families()] [Version data manipulation] Can an attacker corrupt VERSION_DATA_CF_NAME (line 113) to cause validators to query wrong historical versions, enabling time-based attacks where old state is presented as current? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: transaction_db_column_families()] [Transaction summary forgery] Can an attacker manipulate TRANSACTION_SUMMARIES_BY_ACCOUNT_CF_NAME (line 84) independently from TRANSACTION_CF_NAME to show false transaction histories in API responses, enabling social engineering attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: transaction_info_db_column_families()] [Transaction info corruption] Can an attacker exploit the single TRANSACTION_INFO_CF_NAME (line 93) to corrupt transaction metadata while leaving transaction data intact, causing gas calculation errors or incorrect event emission? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: transaction_auxiliary_data_db_column_families()] [Auxiliary data injection] Can an attacker inject malicious data into TRANSACTION_AUXILIARY_DATA_CF_NAME (line 74) that gets processed without validation, potentially executing unauthorized operations or bypassing access controls? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Functions: ledger_db_column_families() and ledger_metadata_db_column_families()] [CF duplication] Do these functions share column families like BLOCK_BY_VERSION_CF_NAME and EPOCH_BY_VERSION_CF_NAME, and can this duplication cause write conflicts where updates to one database don't propagate to the other, creating inconsistent metadata? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Functions: state_kv_db_column_families() and state_kv_db_new_key_column_families()] [Migration race] During migration from old to new key schema, can race conditions cause some writes to go to STATE_VALUE_CF_NAME while reads come from STATE_VALUE_BY_KEY_HASH_CF_NAME, resulting in missing state updates? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Functions: event_db_column_families() and ledger_db_column_families()] [Event CF duplication] Both functions include EVENT_CF_NAME, EVENT_BY_KEY_CF_NAME, etc. Can this lead to event data being split across two databases, causing incomplete event queries and breaking smart contract event listeners? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Ribbon filter DoS] Can an attacker exploit the hybrid_ribbon_filter (line 203) by creating worst-case input patterns that cause ribbon filter construction to take excessive time, delaying block commits and breaking consensus liveness? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Filter block pinning] Does pin_l0_filter_and_index_blocks_in_cache (line 193-195) create a vulnerability where an attacker forces generation of many L0 files with large filters, permanently consuming cache space and degrading performance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: convert_index_type()] [Index type inconsistency] Can different validators configure different index types for the same column family, causing non-deterministic lookup performance that leads to timing-based consensus divergence? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_cfds()] [Deletion collector abuse] Can an attacker trigger the compact_on_deletion_collector_factory (line 174) with ratio 0.4 by creating transactions that cause 40% deletions, forcing continuous compaction that consumes all I/O bandwidth and prevents block processing? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_cfds()] [Compaction amplification] Does the Lz4 compression (line 172) combined with deletion-triggered compaction create amplification where the same data is repeatedly compressed/decompressed during compaction cycles, causing CPU exhaustion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: skip_reporting_cf()] [Metadata corruption blind spot] By excluding DB_METADATA_CF_NAME from reporting (line 128), can an attacker corrupt database metadata without triggering monitoring alerts, allowing prolonged undetected attacks on storage integrity? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: skip_reporting_cf()] [Default CF blind spot] Does excluding DEFAULT_COLUMN_FAMILY_NAME allow attackers to use this CF for covert data storage or command-and-control communication without appearing in database metrics? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_key_extractor()] [Serialization format mismatch] If the Version type serialization format changes but VERSION_SIZE remains constant (line 12), can this cause the prefix extractor to slice keys at wrong positions, corrupting all state lookups? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_key_extractor()] [Endianness attack] Can an attacker exploit endianness differences in Version serialization across different architectures to cause the same key to extract different prefixes on different validators, breaking consensus? (High)
